 ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS, ACUTE LUNG INJURY, [**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic [**Doctor Last Name 281**] with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in sputum.
   .
   # Septic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive for MSSA
   in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L > R
   infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult, patient changed from nafcillin/meropenem/gent to:
   solely Meropenem (day 1 was [**2117-10-31**]).  Now on day 8. Length of
   hospital course?
 f/u with ID (likely pending presence of negative
   blood cultures first)
   - get culture today from HD line and triple lumen (cultured yesterday
   too), and culture tomorrow (until cultures negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - f/u daily CXR
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Too altered for SBT at this
   time despite adequate RSBI
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below); so will postpone doing an SBT today as feel that increased
   sedation will result in an SBT failure
   - Continue pressure support for today
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs
   - No HD today, next planned for Monday
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   - Apply clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before it
   starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too
   - d/c labetalol gtt
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - Increase glargine from 28 to 30, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: right IJ and A line, and HD line.
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room. Family was updated this morning at
   bedside ([**11-7**]).
   Disposition: pending extubation and clinical improvement.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the intensive care unit (ICU) with severe sepsis, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He has been intubated and mechanically ventilated since admission. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including meropenem, and has shown some improvement in his condition. However, he remains critically ill with hypertension, tachycardia, and hyperglycemia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and creatinine (Cr) levels, indicating renal failure. His liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, likely due to prolonged hypotension. His troponin level is elevated, but his cardiac enzymes are no longer trending upward.

The patient's chest radiograph (CXR) shows bilateral infiltrates consistent with ARDS. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows atrial fibrillation with aberrancy, which has been treated with diltiazem and metoprolol. His blood pressure is still elevated, and he is receiving treatment with labetalol and clonidine.

The patient's condition is stable, but he remains critically ill and requires continued close monitoring and treatment.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for continued sepsis and organ dysfunction due to his ongoing infection and underlying comorbidities.
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is likely to continue, and he may require further treatment with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing dialysis therapy.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with aberrancy and elevated troponin level suggest cardiac complications, which may require further treatment with anticoagulation therapy and cardiac medications.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may require further treatment with insulin therapy and close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may require further treatment with antihypertensive medications and close monitoring of blood pressure.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may require further treatment with antibiotics and close monitoring of his respiratory status.
8. Skin integrity: The patient's skin integrity may be compromised due to his prolonged hospitalization and underlying comorbidities, which may require further treatment with wound care and skin substitutes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy as directed by the ID consult.
2. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy as directed by the pulmonologist.
3. Continue dialysis therapy as directed by the nephrologist.
4. Continue anticoagulation therapy and cardiac medications as directed by the cardiologist.
5. Continue insulin therapy and close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
6. Continue antihypertensive medications and close monitoring of blood pressure.
7. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy for pneumonia.
8. Continue wound care and skin substitutes as needed.

The patient's family should be updated regularly on his condition and treatment plan, and they should be encouraged to ask questions and participate in his care.

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antihypertensives, and sedatives. They are being treated in the ICU and are on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a critical condition that requires immediate attention. If left untreated, it can lead to organ failure, including cardiac, renal, and respiratory failure.
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is a life-threatening condition that requires aggressive management. If not treated promptly, it can lead to respiratory failure and death.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a significant concern, especially given their history of malignant hypertension. If not managed effectively, it can lead to cardiac complications, including cardiac arrest.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is a potential complication that requires close monitoring. If not managed effectively, it can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening condition.
5. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity is a potential complication that requires close monitoring. If not managed effectively, it can lead to skin breakdown, sepsis, and death.
6. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient's cardiac dysrhythmia is a potential complication that requires close monitoring. If not managed effectively, it can lead to cardiac arrest and death.
7. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a potential complication that requires close monitoring. If not managed effectively, it can lead to chronic renal failure and death.
8. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a potential complication that requires close monitoring. If not managed effectively, it can lead to respiratory arrest and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs closely, including temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure.
2. Continue to manage the patient's septic shock aggressively, including administration of antibiotics and fluids.
3. Continue to manage the patient's ARDS aggressively, including administration of oxygen and mechanical ventilation.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension aggressively, including administration of antihypertensives and monitoring of blood pressure.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperglycemia closely, including administration of insulin and monitoring of blood glucose levels.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's impaired skin integrity closely, including administration of wound care and monitoring of wound healing.

 ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS, ACUTE LUNG INJURY, [**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic [**Doctor Last Name 281**] with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive for MSSA
   in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L > R
   infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult, patient changed from nafcillin/meropenem/gent to:
   solely Meropenem (day 1 was [**2117-10-31**]).  Now on day 9. Length of
   hospital course?
 f/u with ID (likely pending presence of negative
   blood cultures first)
   - get culture today from HD line and triple lumen (cultured the prior
   two days too), and culture tomorrow (until cultures negative x48 hours,
   per ID)
   - f/u daily CXR
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Too altered for SBT at this
   time despite adequate RSBI
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below); so will postpone doing an SBT today as feel that increased
   sedation will result in an SBT failure
   - Continue pressure support for today, attempt to decr PEEP to 7 and
   re-eval.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs
   - No HD today, next planned for Monday
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too
   - d/c labetalol gtt
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Apply clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before it
   starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Cont Dilt and Metop.
   - Start Amlodipine 5mg PO daily.
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - Increase glargine from 28 to 30, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: right IJ and A line, and HD line.
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room. Family was updated yesterday morning at
   bedside ([**11-7**]).
   Disposition: pending extubation and clinical improvement.

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the hospital with septic shock (sepsis) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He was intubated and treated with antibiotics, including meropenem, and vasopressors. The patient's condition has stabilized, and he is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and vasoactive medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is oliguric. He may require further management of his renal function, including hemodialysis.
2. Cardiac dysrhythmia: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently experiencing tachycardia. He may require further management of his cardiac rhythm, including anti-arrhythmic medications and cardioversion.
3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and he is receiving treatment with clonidine and amlodipine.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood sugar levels are elevated, and he is receiving treatment with insulin and metformin.
5. Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of pneumonia, which may require further management, including antibiotics and respiratory therapy.
6. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock has resolved, but he may still be at risk for sepsis and septic shock.
7. ARDS: The patient's ARDS has resolved, but he may still require mechanical ventilation and respiratory therapy.
8. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's elevated troponin levels suggest cardiac ischemia, which may require further management, including anti-ischemic medications and cardiac catheterization.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is stable, and he is receiving treatment for his various medical complications. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and he may require further management of his respiratory function. He is also receiving treatment for his hypertension, hyperglycemia, and cardiac dysrhythmia. Further management of his renal function and cardiac ischemia may be necessary. The patient's family was updated yesterday morning, and he is pending extubation and clinical improvement.

   in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L > R
   infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].

   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Too altered for SBT at this
   time despite adequate RSBI
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below); so will postpone doing an SBT today as feel that increased
   sedation will result in an SBT failure
   - Continue pressure support for today
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor

   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .

   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs
   - No HD today, next planned for Monday
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.

   - Apply clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before it

s effectiveness increases

   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too
   - d/c labetalol gtt
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - Increase glargine from 28 to 30, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.

   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the emergency department (ED) with septic shock (septic [**281**]) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated and has been receiving treatment for MSSA pneumonia, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is stable off pressors, with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute (bpm) and a respiratory rate of 24 inspirations per minute (IPM).
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 600 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) is 7.9 x 10^9/L, with a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL and a platelet count of 77 x 10^9/L. The patient's creatinine level is 7.8 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 22 mg/dL.
* Imaging studies: The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) shows bilateral infiltrates, consistent with ARDS. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest shows fluid in the sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia.
* Other medical issues: The patient has a rash on his back, abdomen, and thighs, which is consistent with a drug rash, possibly due to vancomycin (Vanc) or cefepime. The patient is also experiencing tachycardia and hypertension, which may be related to his underlying septic shock.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing further complications from his septic shock, including organ dysfunction and failure.
* ARDS: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure and the need for increased ventilatory support.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD).
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
* Infectious complications: The patient's pneumonia and sepsis may lead to further infectious complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs).
* Neurological complications: The patient's septic shock and ARDS may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy.

Based on the patient's current status and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust his ventilatory support as needed.
* Continue to treat the patient's septic shock with antibiotics and fluids.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management and diuretic therapy as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's tachycardia and hypertension with medication and titrate as needed.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilatory support as needed.
* Consider performing a tracheostomy to facilitate weaning from mechanical ventilation.
* Consider performing a renal replacement therapy (RRT) to manage the patient's AKI.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medication and therapy as needed.

In conclusion, the patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of DM who presented to the ED with septic shock and ARDS. The patient is at risk of developing further complications from his septic shock and ARDS, including organ dysfunction and failure. The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may lead to cardiovascular complications, and his pneumonia and sepsis may lead to further infectious complications. The patient's renal function is elevated, and he is at risk of developing AKI or CKD. The patient's neurological status is also at risk of deterioration.

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old man with diabetes mellitus who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure due to ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia and septic shock. He is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has been on meropenem antibiotics. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7Â°C, heart rate of 79 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 169/72 mmHg. He has a fever, hypertension, hyperglycemia, impaired skin integrity, and sepsis. He is also experiencing cardiac dysrhythmia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and acute renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to his bacteremia and septic shock. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
2. ARDS: The patient's acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may worsen if he is not weaned off mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy. Close monitoring of his respiratory status is necessary to detect any signs of worsening ARDS.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if he is not treated promptly and effectively. Close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels is necessary to detect any signs of worsening renal failure.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if he is not treated promptly and effectively. Close monitoring of his blood pressure and electrolyte levels is necessary to detect any signs of worsening hypertension.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen if he is not treated promptly and effectively. Close monitoring of his blood glucose levels is necessary to detect any signs of worsening hyperglycemia.
6. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may worsen if he is not treated promptly and effectively. Close monitoring of his skin integrity and wound healing is necessary to detect any signs of worsening impaired skin integrity.
7. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient's cardiac dysrhythmia may worsen if he is not treated promptly and effectively. Close monitoring of his cardiac rhythm and electrolyte levels is necessary to detect any signs of worsening cardiac dysrhythmia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple complex medical conditions. The patient's chief complaint is Klebsiella pneumonia, respiratory failure, and septic shock.

The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. They are also receiving vasopressors to support their blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil count
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels, indicating acute kidney injury
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac injury
* Elevated blood glucose levels, indicating hyperglycemia
* Elevated levels of liver enzymes, including alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST), indicating liver injury

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Respiratory distress with bilateral wheezing and rhonchi
* Cardiovascular instability with tachycardia and hypertension
* Neurological instability with altered mental status and decreased responsiveness

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypertension, malignant (hypertensive crisis, hypertensive emergency)
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Pneumonia, other
* Hyperglycemia
* Impaired skin integrity
* Sepsis, severe (with organ dysfunction)
* Cardiac dysrhythmia, other
* Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS, acute lung injury)

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure due to ARDS or pneumonia
* Cardiac arrest due to cardiac dysrhythmia or hypotension
* Renal failure progression or acute kidney injury
* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction or failure
* Hypertensive crisis or hypertensive emergency
* Hyperglycemic crisis or diabetic ketoacidosis
* Impaired skin integrity leading to pressure ulcers or infections
* Neurological deterioration or stroke due to sepsis or cardiac arrest

The patient's code status is full code, indicating that they are willing to receive all necessary life-sustaining treatments, including cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and mechanical ventilation. The patient's disposition is ICU, indicating that they will continue to receive critical care in the intensive care unit.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic [**Doctor Last Name 281**] with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive for MSSA
   in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L > R
   infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult, patient changed from nafcillin/meropenem/gent to:
   solely Meropenem (day 1 was [**2117-10-31**]).  Now on day 9. Length of
   hospital course?
 f/u with ID (likely pending presence of negative
   blood cultures first)
   - get cultures daily from HD line and triple lumen (until cultures
   negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - f/u daily CXR
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   - Consider bronchoscopy.
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below).
   - Continue pressure support for today, attempt to decr PEEP to 7 and
   re-eval.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, HD per renal.
   - HD yesterday.
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increase amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before
   it starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Cont Dilt and Metop.
   - Increase Amlodipine to 10 mg PO daily.
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - glargine increased to 30, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: right IJ and A line, and HD line.
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room. Family was updated yesterday morning at
   bedside ([**11-7**]).
   Disposition: pending extubation and clinical improvement.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) who presents with septic shock, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.9Â°C (100.2Â°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 153/69 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 inspirations per minute (ins/min)
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 244 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 5.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 186 mg/dL
* Glucose: 193 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na+ 139 mmol/L, K+ 4.1 mmol/L, Cl- 100 mmol/L
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.9 g/dL
* LDH: 215 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.6 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Bilateral infiltrates, with no signs of empyema or other clear source of infection.
* CT scan: L > R infiltrates, with fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypertension (HTN)
* Malignant hypertension (Hypertensive crisis, hypertensive emergency)
* Fever (Hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Pneumonia, other
* Hyperglycemia
* Impaired skin integrity
* Sepsis, severe (with or without organ dysfunction)
* Cardiac dysrhythmia, other
* Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

The patient's medications include:

* Amlodipine 5mg
* Propofol drip
* Diltiazem 30mg qid
* Metoprolol 125mg tid
* Clonidine patch 0.2
* Meropenem
* Fentanyl 25 mcg/hour
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Flowsheet data:
	+ Vital signs
	+ Hemodynamic monitoring
	+ Fluid balance

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's conditions and medications include:

* Hypertensive crisis or hypertensive emergency
* Cardiac arrhythmia or cardiac arrest
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury
* Respiratory failure or ARDS
* Sepsis or septic shock
* Pneumonia or other infections
* Hyperglycemia or diabetic ketoacidosis
* Impaired skin integrity or skin breakdown
* Hypothermia or hypothermia-related complications

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies.
* Adjust the patient's medications as needed to manage their conditions and prevent complications.
* Consider bronchoscopy to assess the patient's respiratory status and rule out other potential causes of respiratory failure.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust their fluid management and medication regimen accordingly.
* Continue to provide supportive care, including oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, and nutritional support.
* Consider extubation and weaning from mechanical ventilation once the patient's respiratory status improves.

   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below).
   - Continue pressure support for today, attempt to decr PEEP to 7 and
   re-eval.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   - Will decrease fentanyl, propofol and start precedex x 24 hours to
   attempt to extubate tomorrow
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, HD per renal.
   - HD yesterday.
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 500 mL.
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increase amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before
   it starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Cont Dilt and Metop.
   - Increase Amlodipine to 10 mg PO daily.
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - glargine increased to 40 QD, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes and septicemia due to Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) and Klebsiella pneumoniae. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). His condition has been complicated by hypertension, tachycardia, and renal failure. He has also had episodes of atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia.

The patient's current medications include:

* Amlodipine 5mg daily
* Diltiazem 30mg qid
* Metoprolol 125mg tid
* Hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs
* Propofol 15 mcg/Kg/min
* Fentanyl 25 mcg/hour
* Clonidine patch 0.2
* Glargine 40mg QD
* ISS 20U insulin given in 24 hours
* Nutren 40cc/hr tube feeds

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC 8.2
* Hct 25.1
* Plt 244
* Cr 5.5
* TCO2 28
* Glucose 193
* Amylase 57
* Lipase 0
* LDH 215 IU/L
* Ca++ 7.9 mg/dL
* Mg++ 1.6 mg/dL
* PO4 5.6 mg/dL
* Albumin 1.9 g/dL

Potential medical complications:

* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is currently elevated, which can lead to cardiovascular complications such as heart failure, stroke, and kidney damage.
* Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is currently elevated, which can lead to cardiovascular complications such as atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and heart failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is currently elevated, which can lead to acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
* ARDS: The patient's lung injury can lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome, which can cause respiratory failure and death.
* Sepsis: The patient's septicemia can lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction and death.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which can cause cardiac arrest and death.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely.
* Adjust the patient's medications as necessary to control his blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory status.
* Continue to provide supportive care, including mechanical ventilation and tube feeds.
* Consider extubation once the patient's respiratory status improves.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
* Consider the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia when assessing his cardiac rhythm.
* Consider the patient's history of septicemia and ARDS when assessing his overall condition.

   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.

   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, HD per renal.
   - HD yesterday.

   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring

   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes, septicemia, and pneumonia, currently intubated and ventilated in the ICU. He has been diagnosed with hypertensive crisis, fever, pneumonia, hyperglycemia, impaired skin integrity, sepsis, cardiac dysrhythmia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He has undergone multiple interventions, including antibiotic therapy, dialysis, and medication adjustments to manage his hypertension, tachycardia, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypertensive Crisis: The patient's blood pressure remains elevated, and his hypertensive crisis is not fully controlled. This increases the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction, stroke, and cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septicemia is ongoing, and his blood cultures remain positive for MSSA. This increases the risk of septic shock, organ dysfunction, and mortality.
3. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is severe, and his oxygen requirements are high. This increases the risk of respiratory failure, ventilator-associated lung injury, and mortality.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and his creatinine level is elevated. This increases the risk of acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.
5. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient's cardiac dysrhythmia is ongoing, and his troponin level is elevated. This increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrest.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels remain elevated, and his diabetes is not fully controlled. This increases the risk of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome, diabetic ketoacidosis, and mortality.
7. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's skin integrity is impaired, and he has developed a rash. This increases the risk of skin infections, sepsis, and mortality.
8. Infection: The patient's infections, including pneumonia, septicemia, and skin infections, increase the risk of sepsis, organ dysfunction, and mortality.
9. Ventilator-Associated Complications: The patient's prolonged ventilation increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia, ventilator-associated lung injury, and mortality.
10. Delirium: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and multiple interventions increase the risk of delirium, which can lead to cognitive impairment, mood disturbances, and increased risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy and monitor blood cultures for signs of bacterial clearance.
2. Adjust medication regimens to manage hypertension, tachycardia, and hyperglycemia.
3. Continue dialysis and monitor renal function to prevent acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
4. Monitor cardiac function and adjust medication regimens to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and myocardial infarction.
5. Monitor skin integrity and treat any skin infections promptly to prevent sepsis and mortality.
6. Consider bronchoscopy to evaluate lung injury and guide management of ARDS.
7. Monitor for signs of delirium and adjust sedation and analgesia regimens as needed to prevent cognitive impairment and mood disturbances.
8. Consider extubation and weaning from ventilation once the patient's respiratory function improves and the risk of ventilator-associated complications decreases.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus (DM), septic shock, pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure (ARF), and hypertension. He has been intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7Â°C (99.9Â°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 153/69 mmHg (123/43-185/89 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 28 inspirations per minute (ins/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP) is elevated, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 15 mmHg, indicating hypervolemia.

The patient's laboratory results are:

* Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 8.2, Hct 25.1, Plt 244
* Blood chemistry: Cr 7.8, Glucose 193, Albumin 1.9 g/dL, LDH 215 IU/L, Ca++ 7.9 mg/dL, Mg++ 1.6 mg/dL, PO4 5.6 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na+ 139 mEq/L, K+ 4.1 mEq/L, Cl- 26 mEq/L
* Coagulation studies: PT 13.6, PTT 31.2, INR 1.2

The patient's imaging studies are:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Bilateral infiltrates, consistent with ARDS
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: L > R infiltrates, no sign of empyema

The patient's medication list includes:

* Antibiotics: Meropenem
* Sedatives: Propofol, Fentanyl
* Antihypertensives: Clonidine patch, Amlodipine, Diltiazem
* Anti-diabetic medications: Glargine, Insulin sliding scale (ISS)
* Anti-arrhythmics: Metoprolol, Adenosine
* Prophylactic medications: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI

The patient's medical complications are:

* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and he is at risk of developing hypertensive crisis.
* Fever: The patient has a temperature of 37.7Â°C (99.9Â°F), which may be related to his underlying infections.
* ARF: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk of developing further kidney damage.
* Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of pneumonia, and his CXR shows bilateral infiltrates consistent with ARDS.
* Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient has had episodes of atrial fibrillation and supraventricular tachycardia, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics and antihypertensives
* Monitoring for signs of hypertensive crisis and adjusting medication as needed
* Managing the patient's blood glucose levels
* Continuing to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjusting medication as needed
* Considering extubation and weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Monitoring for signs of ARF and adjusting medication as needed
* Considering dialysis if the patient's kidney function does not improve.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic [**Doctor Last Name 281**] with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive for MSSA
   in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L > R
   infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult, patient changed from nafcillin/meropenem/gent to:
   solely Meropenem (day 1 was [**2117-10-31**]).  Now on day 9. Length of
   hospital course?
 f/u with ID (likely pending presence of negative
   blood cultures first)
   - get cultures daily from HD line and triple lumen (until cultures
   negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - f/u daily CXR
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below).
   - Continue pressure support for today, attempt to decr PEEP to 7 and
   re-eval.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, HD per renal.
   - HD yesterday.
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increase amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before
   it starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Cont Dilt and Metop.
   - Increase Amlodipine to 10 mg PO daily.
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - glargine increased to 30, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: right IJ and A line, and HD line.
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room. Family was updated yesterday morning at
   bedside ([**11-7**]).
   Disposition: pending extubation and clinical improvement.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.9Â°C (100.2Â°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 153/69 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) 15, mean arterial pressure (MAP) 123 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 8.2 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit (Hct): 25.1%
* Platelet count (Plt): 244 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 7.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 186 mg/dL
* Serum electrolytes: Na+ 139 mmol/L, K+ 4.1 mmol/L, Cl- 100 mmol/L
* Blood glucose: 193 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.21 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L

The patient's medical history includes:

* Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) pneumonia
* Klebsiella pneumoniae in the sputum
* Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the sputum
* GNR (Gram-negative rods) in the blood
* History of atrial fibrillation (AFib) with aberrancy
* History of tachycardia
* History of hypertension

The patient's current medications include:

* Meropenem
* Propofol
* Diltiazem
* Metoprolol
* Amlodipine
* Clonidine patch
* Glargine
* ISS (insulin sensitivity test)
* Tylenol (acetaminophen)

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Sedated, tracking, and PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Regular rate and rhythm
* Fairly clear lungs with few crackles and scattered wheezes
* Obese with +BS (brachial swelling)
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* 1+ pedal edema
* Puffy hands and face

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypertension
* Malignant hypertension
* Fever
* Hyperglycemia
* Impaired skin integrity
* Sepsis, severe
* Cardiac dysrhythmia
* Renal failure, acute
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue meropenem
* Increase propofol to help with hypertension and tachycardia
* Continue pressure support ventilation
* Wean FiO2 to 40% and PEEP to 7
* Monitor for signs of ARDS
* Continue diltiazem and metoprolol
* Increase amlodipine to 10 mg daily
* Monitor for signs of hypertension
* Continue clonidine patch
* Monitor for signs of DM
* Continue ISS and glargine
* Monitor for signs of LFT elevation

The patient's disposition is pending extubation and clinical improvement.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus (DM) who is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure caused by ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia. The patient has a history of septic shock with ESBL Klebsiella bacteremia, and is currently being treated with meropenem.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.9Â°C (100.2Â°F), heart rate of 88 beats per minute, blood pressure of 175/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 600 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.2 K/Î¼L, hemoglobin of 7.5 g/dL, platelet count of 244 K/Î¼L, and creatinine of 5.5 mg/dL. The patient's blood glucose level is 193 mg/dL.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Hypertension: The patient has a blood pressure of 175/89 mmHg, which is elevated. He is being treated with diltiazem and metoprolol.
2. Fever: The patient has a temperature of 37.9Â°C (100.2Â°F), which is slightly elevated. He is being treated with antibiotics.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia, which is a serious infection.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a blood glucose level of 193 mg/dL, which is elevated. He is being treated with insulin.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a wound or skin lesion that is not healing properly.
6. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock with ESBL Klebsiella bacteremia, which is a life-threatening condition.
7. Cardiac dysrhythmia: The patient has an abnormal heart rhythm, which is being treated with medications.
8. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which is being treated with hemodialysis.
9. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient has ARDS, which is a serious lung condition.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing antibiotics to treat the ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia.
2. Managing the patient's hypertension with medications.
3. Treating the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin.
4. Providing wound care to promote healing of the skin lesion.
5. Managing the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and other supportive measures.
6. Monitoring the patient's cardiac rhythm and treating any abnormalities.
7. Providing hemodialysis to treat the patient's acute renal failure.
8. Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and treating any abnormalities.
9. Considering the possibility of extubation and weaning the patient off mechanical ventilation.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and treatment to manage his multiple medical complications.

 HYPERTENSION, MALIGNANT (HYPERTENSIVE CRISIS, HYPERTENSIVE EMERGENCY)

 PNEUMONIA, OTHER
 HYPERGLYCEMIA

 ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS, ACUTE LUNG INJURY, [**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic [**Doctor Last Name 281**] with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult, patient changed from nafcillin/meropenem/gent to:
   solely Meropenem (day 1 was [**2117-10-31**]).  Now on day 9. Will treat with
   14 total days Meropenem since first negative blood culture = course
   should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**].
   - get cultures daily from HD line and triple lumen (until cultures
   negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - Requested speciation and sensitivities of GNRs in sputum cxr, as
   concern for treatment failure given growth while pt on appropriate abx
   therapy.
   - f/u daily CXR
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Now intubated 18 days
   ([**11-10**]).
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   - Will decrease fentanyl, propofol and start precedex x 24 hours to
   attempt to extubate today.
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, HD per renal.
   - HD on Monday.
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 500 mL.
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before
   it starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Cont Dilt and Metop.
   - Increased Amlodipine to 10 mg PO daily.
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - glargine increased to 40 QD, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: right IJ and A line, and HD line.
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room. Family was updated yesterday morning at
   bedside ([**11-7**]).
   Disposition: pending extubation and clinical improvement

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the hospital with septic shock and pneumonia. He was intubated and treated with antibiotics, including meropenem, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been complicated by acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), and hypertension.

The patient's current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 101Â°F (38.3Â°C)
* Heart rate: 95 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 181/86 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 92%
* SpO2: 92%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 7.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 277 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 7.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 226 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: potassium (K+): 4.3 mmol/L, sodium (Na+): 139 mmol/L, chloride (Cl-): 103 mmol/L, bicarbonate (HCO3-): 26 mmol/L
* Blood glucose: 193 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.9 g/dL
* LDH: 215 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): bilateral infiltrates, no pneumothorax or other abnormalities
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: L > R infiltrates, no sign of empyema

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
3. AKI: The patient's AKI is likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
6. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrhythmias are likely to worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment. The plan is to continue antibiotics, mechanical ventilation, and hemodialysis, and to monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely. The patient's family has been updated on his condition, and he will be extubated once his condition improves and he is clinically stable.

 ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS, ACUTE LUNG INJURY, [**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic [**Doctor Last Name 281**] with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive for MSSA
   in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L > R
   infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic [**Year (2 digits) 281**]. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult, patient changed from nafcillin/meropenem/gent to:
   solely Meropenem (day 1 was [**2117-10-31**]).  Now on day 9. Will treat with
   14 total days Meropenem since first negative blood culture = course
   should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**].
   - get cultures daily from HD line and triple lumen (until cultures
   negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - f/u daily CXR
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.
   - Increasing propofol to help with hypertension/tachycardia (see
   below).
   - Continue pressure support for today, attempt to decr PEEP to 7 and
   re-eval.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Daily CXR
   - If anxious d/t intubation, try zyprexa
   - Will decrease fentanyl, propofol and start precedex x 24 hours to
   attempt to extubate tomorrow
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, HD per renal.
   - HD on Monday.
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 500 mL.
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension yesterday & today.
   - Adenosine if SVT tonight to see if sinus; if need to [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] so in
   synced mode; adenosine is at bedside; alternatively could also try
   diltiazem is another SVT occurs as that broke it previously too.
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.2 (know that there will be a delay before
   it starts affecting BP)
   - Increase propofol until the clonidine patch
s effectiveness increases
   - Cont Dilt and Metop.
   - Increased Amlodipine to 10 mg PO daily.
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars were elevated, now much better controlled.
   - glargine increased to 40 QD, and continue ISS
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of [**First Name3 (LF) 281**] and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; no IVF, lytes prn, on tube feeds nutren at 40cc/hr, HD schedule
   per renal
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: right IJ and A line, and HD line.
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room. Family was updated yesterday morning at
   bedside ([**11-7**]).
   Disposition: pending extubation and clinical improvement
