   Assessment and Plan
   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   - s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - F/u ID recs
   - get cultures daily  (until cultures negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - daily CXR
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Daily CXR
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   -          improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened
   after lasix given for resp distress
   -          - will add free H20 flushes
   -          Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.

   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   -          improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened
   after lasix given for resp distress
   -          - will add free H20 flushes
   -          Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes, septic shock, pneumonia, and respiratory distress. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of septic shock, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He was intubated and received mechanical ventilation. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime, and has shown improvement in his respiratory status. He is currently on non-invasive ventilation and is being weaned off the ventilator.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still tenuous, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation or non-invasive ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is not fully resolved, and he may require continued antibiotic therapy.
3. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is still present, and he may require continued oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is still present, and he may require continued treatment with fluids and electrolytes.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is still present, and he may require continued treatment with antihypertensive medications.
6. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is still present, and he may require continued treatment with antitachycardia medications.
7. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is still present, and he may require continued monitoring and treatment.
8. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is improving, but he may still require continued monitoring and treatment.
9. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia is still present, and he may require continued treatment with calcium supplements.
10. Elevated troponin: The patient's elevated troponin levels are still present, and he may require continued monitoring and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and monitor his response to therapy.
3. Continue to treat the patient's ARDS with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation, and monitor his response to therapy.
4. Continue to treat the patient's hypernatremia with fluids and electrolytes, and monitor his response to therapy.
5. Continue to treat the patient's hypertension with antihypertensive medications, and monitor his response to therapy.
6. Continue to treat the patient's tachycardia with antitachycardia medications, and monitor his response to therapy.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's altered mental status and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's hypocalcemia and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's elevated troponin levels and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

s renal function

   - f/u daily CXR, sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Tachypnea on [**11-12**], unclear etiology
   (positional, AMS, PE). Improving, not de-satting, but still with incr
   work of breathing.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Daily CXR
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is likely due to
   toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   Will cont to monitor for 2-3 days
   (from [**11-12**]), and if no improvement can consider head CT, EEG
   monitoring and AMS w/u. Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr currently elevated at 7.8, currently oliguric, which will
   likely continue while he is so sick. Urine output increasing
   considerably over past few days.
   - F/u renal recs, holding on HD for now
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   - pulled HD line ([**11-11**]) given positive blood cultures
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   - improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight.
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider dc
ing and starting
   ACEI in [**12-4**] days when stable improved kidney fxn
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - consider starting ACEi tomorrow instead of hydralazine
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars previously poorly controlled.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5 days
   as of [**11-12**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient remains intubated and on non-invasive ventilation (NIV) with a face tent and high-flow nebulizer. The patient has a history of pneumonia, respiratory distress, and acute respiratory failure (ARF). The recent CXR shows improving left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrate, and the patient's oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 94% on 60% FiO2.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of septic shock, tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation (AFib). The patient's blood pressure (BP) is stable off pressors, and the patient is on clonidine patch 0.3, diltiazem 30mg qid, metoprolol 125mg tid, and amlodipine 10mg daily. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a sinus rhythm with a rate of 101 bpm.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status (AMS) likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. The patient is being monitored for 2-3 days, and if no improvement, the patient may undergo head computed tomography (CT), electroencephalogram (EEG), and/or altered mental status workup.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine (Cr) level of 7.8 mg/dL. The patient is oliguric, but urine output is increasing. The patient is being treated with furosemide (Lasix) and is holding on hemodialysis (HD) for now.
* Endocrine: The patient has diabetes mellitus (DM) with poorly controlled blood sugars. The patient is being treated with glargine 50mg QD and insulin sliding scale (ISS).
* Hematological: The patient has elevated troponin levels, likely due to demand ischemia in the setting of shock and tachycardia. The patient is no longer trending cardiac enzymes.
* Hepatic: The patient has mild liver function test (LFT) elevation likely due to prolonged hypotension. The patient's LFTs are being trended, and the patient is being treated with limited tylenol.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARF may progress, and the patient may require more invasive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of septic shock, tachycardia, and AFib may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's AMS may worsen, and the patient may require further evaluation and treatment, such as head CT or EEG.
4. Renal complications: The patient's AKI may progress, and the patient may require more aggressive renal replacement therapy, such as HD or continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and septic shock may lead to further infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI).
6. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's history of septic shock and tachycardia may lead to further bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria.
7. Endocrine complications: The patient's DM may worsen, and the patient may require more aggressive insulin therapy or other endocrine treatments.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient's treatment plan should be individualized to address the patient's specific needs and complications.

The patient is a 37-year-old man with diabetes mellitus (DM) who was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with respiratory failure due to Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella pneumonia. He has been treated with antibiotics, including cefipime, vancomycin, and meropenem, and is currently receiving non-invasive ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.1Â°C, heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 142/68 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 29 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95%. He is unable to provide a history due to encephalopathy.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has severe respiratory failure due to pneumonia, which is not responding to treatment.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient has high sodium levels, which may be causing symptoms such as headache, nausea, and vomiting.
3. Dyspnea: The patient is experiencing shortness of breath, which may be related to his pneumonia or respiratory failure.
4. Impaired balance: The patient is at risk of falling due to his respiratory failure and altered mental status.
5. Impaired knowledge: The patient is unable to provide a history due to encephalopathy.
6. Impaired muscle performance: The patient may be experiencing muscle weakness or fatigue due to his respiratory failure.
7. Impaired transfers: The patient may be at risk of falling or experiencing difficulty transferring due to his respiratory failure and altered mental status.
8. Hypertension: The patient has high blood pressure, which may be causing symptoms such as headache, nausea, and vomiting.
9. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which is not responding to treatment.
10. Hyperglycemia: The patient has high blood sugar levels, which may be causing symptoms such as increased thirst, urination, and fatigue.
11. Impaired skin integrity: The patient may be at risk of developing skin ulcers or pressure sores due to his respiratory failure and altered mental status.
12. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be causing symptoms such as fatigue, nausea, and vomiting.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may experience worsening respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory arrest or death.
2. Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis due to his pneumonia, which can lead to organ failure and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient may experience worsening kidney function, which can lead to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient may experience cardiovascular complications, such as hypertension, tachycardia, or cardiac arrest, due to his pneumonia or respiratory failure.
5. Neurological complications: The patient may experience neurological complications, such as encephalopathy, seizures, or stroke, due to his pneumonia or respiratory failure.
6. Skin complications: The patient may experience skin complications, such as pressure sores or skin ulcers, due to his respiratory failure and altered mental status.
7. Infection: The patient may develop new infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, due to his immunosuppressed state.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of his medical complications to prevent further deterioration.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   - s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - F/u ID recs
   - get cultures daily  (until cultures negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - daily CXR
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Daily CXR
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   - improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened after
   lasix given for resp distress
   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral

   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number

   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the hospital with septic shock and pneumonia. He was intubated and treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem, for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) and Gram-negative rods in his blood and sputum. He has been weaned off pressors and is currently off pressors. He has also been treated for hypernatremia, hypertension, and tachycardia.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR, high oxygen requirement, and frequent suctioning and nebs.
* Cardiovascular: Stable blood pressure, but tachycardia and hypertension.
* Neurological: Altered mental status, likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.
* Renal: Improved renal function, but still oliguric.
* Endocrine: Poorly controlled blood sugars.
* Dermatological: Rash on back, abdomen, and thighs, likely due to antibiotic reaction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen requirement suggest ongoing pneumonia.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock may recur if his infection is not adequately treated.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to seizures, coma, or death if not treated.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may lead to cardiac complications, such as heart failure or stroke.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may lead to cardiac complications, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
6. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may progress to coma or death if not treated.
7. Renal Failure: The patient's oliguric renal failure may progress to anuria or acute kidney injury if not treated.
8. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: The patient's poorly controlled blood sugars may lead to diabetic ketoacidosis if not treated.
9. Skin Infection: The patient's rash may progress to a skin infection if not treated.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan should focus on treating his ongoing pneumonia, septic shock, hypernatremia, hypertension, tachycardia, altered mental status, and renal failure. He should also be monitored for potential complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and coma. The patient's antibiotics should be continued, and his electrolyte levels should be monitored closely. His blood sugars should be controlled, and his renal function should be monitored.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**], growing
   Pseudomonas and Klebsiella.  s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   -
   - F/u ID recs
   - daily CXR
   - d/c daily  cultures given negative x48 hours, per ID
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   - improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened after
   lasix given for resp distress
   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the hospital with septic shock and pneumonia. He has been intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving antibiotics for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) and other Gram-negative bacteria. The patient has had several complications, including hypernatremia, hypertension, tachycardia, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition is stable, with his blood pressure controlled and his oxygen requirement decreased. However, he still requires frequent suctioning and nebulizer treatments due to his respiratory distress. His mental status has improved, but he is still experiencing episodes of respiratory distress and requires close monitoring.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), indicating renal dysfunction. His urine output has increased, but his glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is likely normal. His blood glucose levels have been poorly controlled, but he is currently receiving insulin and sliding-scale insulin.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains tenuous, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Renal dysfunction: The patient's creatinine and BUN levels are elevated, indicating ongoing renal dysfunction. He may require further treatment, such as dialysis, to manage his electrolyte imbalance.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, which may contribute to his altered mental status and respiratory distress. He may require further treatment to correct his electrolyte imbalance.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure remains elevated, which may contribute to his tachycardia and altered mental status. He may require further treatment to control his blood pressure.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate remains elevated, which may be contributing to his altered mental status and respiratory distress. He may require further treatment to control his heart rate.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status remains altered, which may be contributing to his respiratory distress and tachycardia. He may require further treatment to improve his mental status.
7. Skin integrity: The patient has developed a rash on his back, abdomen, and thighs, which may be related to his antibiotic treatment. He may require further treatment to manage his skin integrity.

Overall, the patient's condition remains complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**], growing
   Pseudomonas and Klebsiella.  s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   - F/u ID recs
   - daily CXR
   - d/c daily  cultures given negative x48 hours, per ID
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia/Volume Status:  Improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr
   overnight but then worsened after lasix given for resp distress.
   - D5W x2L
   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h PM of [**11-14**]; continue
   - f/u Renal recs
   - Assess I/O and use Lasix for diuresis if necessary in PM
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, increase SSI for sugars in 200
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2117-11-15**] 12:26 AM 45 mL/hour

   Lines:

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), septic shock, pneumonia, and acute renal failure (ARF).
* He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure.
* He has a history of tachycardia and hypertension, which has resolved in part due to treatment.
* He has a rash on his back, abdomen, and thighs, which is suspected to be a drug rash related to vancomycin or cefepime.
* He has mild liver function test (LFT) elevation, which is likely related to prolonged hypotension.
* He has elevated troponin levels, which are likely due to demand ischemia in the setting of shock and persistent tachycardia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia:** The patient's pneumonia is likely to continue to be a source of infection and respiratory distress.
2. **Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):** The patient's ARF is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require further renal replacement therapy (RRT) if his kidney function does not improve.
3. **Hypertension:** The patient's hypertension is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require further treatment to control his blood pressure.
4. **Tachycardia:** The patient's tachycardia is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require further treatment to control his heart rate.
5. **Rash:** The patient's rash is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require further treatment to manage his symptoms.
6. **Hyperglycemia:** The patient's hyperglycemia is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require further treatment to manage his blood glucose levels.
7. **Seizure risk:** The patient's elevated troponin levels and history of tachycardia and hypertension may increase his risk of seizure activity.
8. **Cardiac arrhythmias:** The patient's history of tachycardia and hypertension may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation.
9. **Infection:** The patient's pneumonia and ARF may increase his risk of developing further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
10. **Nutritional deficiencies:** The patient's prolonged hospitalization and nutritional requirements may increase his risk of developing nutritional deficiencies, including protein-energy malnutrition.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension and tachycardia with medications and lifestyle modifications.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin therapy and dietary modifications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's rash and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
6. Consider further treatment for the patient's pneumonia, including antibiotics and bronchodilators.
7. Consider further treatment for the patient's ARF, including renal replacement therapy and dialysis.
8. Consider further treatment for the patient's elevated troponin levels, including cardiology consultation and further testing.
9. Consider further treatment for the patient's seizure risk, including seizure prophylaxis and further testing.
10. Consider further treatment for the patient's cardiac arrhythmias, including cardiology consultation and further testing.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   - s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - F/u ID recs
   - daily CXR
   - d/c daily  cultures given negative x48 hours, per ID
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   - improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened after
   lasix given for resp distress
   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2117-11-15**] 12:26 AM 45 mL/hour

   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2117-11-15**] 12:26 AM 45 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU for septic shock and pneumonia. He has a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) and has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He has bilateral infiltrates on CXR and requires high oxygen requirements, suggesting acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with clonidine, diltiazem, and metoprolol. He has also had episodes of tachycardia and atrial fibrillation, which have been treated with adenosine and diltiazem.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is oliguric. His creatinine level is elevated, and he is being treated with fluids and diuretics.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. He has also had episodes of seizure-like activity.
* Hematological: The patient has elevated troponin levels, which are likely due to demand ischemia in the setting of shock and tachycardia.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a rash on his back, abdomen, and thighs, which is consistent with a drug rash.
* Laboratory results:
	+ CBC: WBC 8.5, Hct 26.3, Plt 73
	+ Electrolytes: Na 149 mEq/L, K 4.1 mEq/L, Cl 110 mEq/L
	+ Blood glucose: 210 mg/dL
	+ LFTs: ALT 23, AST 42, Alk Phos 132, T Bili 0.9
	+ Renal function: Cr 2.7, BUN 21 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia may lead to cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's AKI may worsen, leading to renal failure.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to neurological complications such as seizures or coma.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's rash may worsen, leading to gastrointestinal complications such as diarrhea or abdominal pain.
* Hematological complications: The patient's elevated troponin levels may indicate cardiac ischemia, which may lead to cardiac complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following interventions may be necessary:

* Continue respiratory support with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
* Manage hypertension with antihypertensive medications and monitor for cardiac complications.
* Monitor renal function and adjust fluid and diuretic therapy as needed.
* Monitor neurological status and adjust sedation and analgesia as needed.
* Monitor gastrointestinal symptoms and adjust antacid and antidiarrheal therapy as needed.
* Monitor hematological parameters and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust therapy as needed to prevent potential complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with Klebsiella pneumonia and respiratory failure. The patient's condition remains unchanged, with no NIPPV overnight. The patient has a large mucous plug suctioned yesterday, which may have alleviated some respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9Â°C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%, and they are receiving high-flow nasal oxygen therapy.

The patient's physical examination is notable for the presence of rhonchorous breath sounds throughout the chest, indicating possible pulmonary edema. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, and they have no signs of pain or discomfort.

Laboratory results show hypernatremia (sodium levels at 146 mmol/L), hypertension (blood pressure at 135/75 mmHg), and hyperglycemia (glucose levels at 246 mg/dL). The patient's white blood cell count is elevated at 8.5 K/Î¼L, and their platelet count is normal at 339 K/Î¼L.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels can lead to dehydration, seizures, and coma.
2. Hypertension: Malignant hypertension can cause hypertensive crisis, encephalopathy, and cardiac damage.
3. Hyperglycemia: High blood sugar levels can cause ketoacidosis, coma, and increased risk of infection.
4. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin may be at risk for breakdown and infection.
5. Impaired muscle performance: The patient's muscle weakness may be exacerbated by their respiratory failure and hypernatremia.
6. Impaired knowledge: The patient's cognitive function may be impaired due to their underlying medical conditions.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has Klebsiella pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they require continued oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
9. Septic shock: The patient's hypernatremia and hyperglycemia may indicate septic shock, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.

Based on these findings, the patient requires continued ICU care, including close monitoring of their vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status. The patient's nutritional needs should be met with a full-strength renal diet, and their glycemic control should be maintained with insulin therapy. The patient's skin integrity should be monitored, and their muscle performance should be assessed regularly. The patient's knowledge and cognitive function should be evaluated, and their family should be educated on their condition and treatment plan.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**], growing
   Pseudomonas and Klebsiella.  s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function
   - Continue vancomycin, started on [**11-10**] for GPC, 7 day course, d/c [**11-16**]
   - F/u ID recs
   - hold on daily CXR given continued improvement
   - d/c daily  cultures given negative x48 hours, per ID
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   # Volume Status:  Hypernatremia improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr
   overnight but then worsened after lasix given for resp distress.
   Resolved, now becoming hyponatremic.
   - Hold IVF today; no D5W
   - Decrease free H20 flushes from 300cc q4h PM of [**11-14**] to 200cc q4h
   - Consider U lytes if hyponatremia worsens, though likely [**1-4**] volume
   overload
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L; f/u
   Renal recs
   - Assess I/O and use Lasix for diuresis if necessary in PM
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Decrease Hydralazine from 50mg Q6 hrs to 25mg q6h
   - Consider increasing Lisinopril from 10mg to 20mg daily tomorrow if
   patient
s BP high with decrease of Hydral
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3; titrate down once Hydralazine is weaned
   off
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - Consider initiating Celexa 20mg daily for anxiety with goal of
   d/c
ing Clonazepam once SSRI becomes effective
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, increase SSI for sugars in 200
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.  Resolved Cr, HD line
   removed.
   - F/u renal recs
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU for today as profoundly weak; ideally discharge
   directly to rehab if possible given patient
s insurance
